Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2008 06:25PM Liz08 wrote: Thank you ladies for responding so quickly to my post. About a month ago I was diagnosed with costochondritis which is an inflamation of the cartilage between the ribs and can happen after radiation. I found some information on the web stating that shortness of breath can be related to the chostochondritis rght along with the stress of everything. I never even heard of chostochondritis until about a month ago and there are many opinions on how long it can last. Had a CT scan done just to be sure, which was all clear, thank GOD. Chostochondritis can't be diagnosed by scans but by symptoms.  It's just that any ache, pain, shortness of breath makes me worry about the worst.  I Know most of you understand where I'm coming from.   I just wish this cancer never happened....as I'm sure all of you feel the same way.  (((Hugs))) Liz

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2008 01:33PM Liz08 wrote: Kiwi- please contact the http://www.youngsurvival.org/young-women-and-bc/ this is a group of women who had/have BC and are under 40 you can read some of their stories on their website.  Ask if they know of a forum for women pregnant with BC or if they can direct you to someone who can help you.  If they can't help you contact the American Cancer Society, also you can see if the http://www.networkofstrength.org/ formally Y-me can assist you.  The Y-me was a good resource to me when I was initially diagnosed.  Another resource is John Hopkins in Maryland, they have an ask an expert forum help by Lilly who is a nurse and a 2 X breast cancer survivor, she usually opens the forum for questions on Saturdays. http://www.hopkinsbreastcenter.org/services/ask_expert/ I know you want to make the best decision which involves the least risk for both you and your baby, just keep praying for God to help you make your decision, that's what has helped me. If you have any questions about the above just e-mail me privately and I'll try to help you the best I can, I got diagnosed with BC when my baby was only 8 months old so I too had breast cancer while I was pregnant but was not aware of it.  (((Hugs))) Liz
Posts.Title: chemo while pregnant??? kiwi72 DoreenF

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2008 06:56AM Liz08 wrote: Kiwi- Congraulations on your pregnancy.    How about getting a 2nd and 3rd opinion regarding treatment or going a to a large cancer center that has experience treating pregnant women with cancer.  I got several (10) opinions regarding my treatment, it's a long story but the good news is the same recommendations were made by all the doctors which made my decision easier.  Also, how about  waiting to do chemo till after you have the baby, what would the chances of recurrence be then?  You did have a grade 2 tumor not grade 3, which is good too.  I'm a little confused with your node status; your signature states that you had 1 out of 3 nodes + but in you posting you indicated that you were node negative. Having a positive or negative node does make a difference on how agressive you should be in your treatment.  You do have some difficult decisions to make, I pray that you do make a decision that you will be at peace with. Take peace in the fact that this cancer was caught very early and that it's very treatable. (((Hugs))) Liz

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 09:15AM - edited Jul 17, 2008 09:16AM by Liz08 I've experienced comments of BC being no big deal to it being a death sentence sooner or later.  One day I ran into someone I worked with at a hospital for many years, she asked me how I'm doing (I assumed she knew that have had BC since we know many of the same people) so I told her that I'm doing as well as can be expected. Well, I was wrong, she didn't know about my BC but after I told her she went on to tell me how someone who we worked with just died the other day of BC.  The person was in remission for 16years and "the cancer came back with a vengence and she went down quickly" were the exact words I was told.  Talk about insensitive comments! I know what cancer is and what it is capable of doing but a little tact and consideration would be nice.  Especially from a professional who works in a medical  environment.  We just need to learn not to take insensitive comments to heart and not let them bother us but that's easier said then done.....hopefully with time it will get easier.
Posts.Title: Very Angry! LisaG42 BessB

Posts.Content: Liz08 wrote: Hi everyone- I was wondering if anyone who has had radiation has experienced muscle tightness in the chest area.  I finished rads on May 20th and my chest muscles feel extremely tight and at times it's difficult to take a deep  breath as if I can't stretch my chest muscles enough to get enough air in. I hope that makes sense.  When I lay down on my side I do not have the issues taking a deep breath and my chest does not feel as tight.  I know it sounds strange but these are my symptoms. In the past I have had costochondritis/pluerisy and several scans to rule things out but the chest still feels very tight. I am very frustrated with this and not sure what to do, if anyone has had these type of symptoms, please take a moment to post so that I don't feel like I'm the only one that this has happened to and what have you done for relief or how long did it take to get relief.  Thank you all.       Dx: 1/16/08, Stage T1mic, DCIS, Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Chest Muscle Tight after rads Liz08 Liz08

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 07:36PM - edited Sep 2, 2008 07:37PM by Liz08 Thank you ladies for responding. I have been trying to gently stretch on my large exercise ball 2-3 times per day. That does seem to help somewhat but I also probably(?) have some radiation damage to my lungs.  Today one of my doctors agreed that one of the side effects of radiation could be the lungs producing less surfactant which is responsible for helping the lungs expand when taking a deep breath.  But relieved by aerobic exercise such as brisk walking since I can actually breath easier after my workout.  Symptoms like this corelates to the surfactant issue, according to one of my doctors.  Now I have to wait till Oct. 10th when I see the pulmonologist to confirm this and determine a course of treatment.  A member posted a breast massage video from u-tube which I found helpful as well.
Posts.Title: Chest Muscle Tight after rads Liz08 Liz08

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 09:25PM Liz08 wrote: Lisa- May be this rad oncologist is from the old school of thought despite his age; that all women who have had breast cancer should just have a mastectomy.  How would he feel if had cancer on the tip of his pecker, would he want his whole pecker to be cut off ??? Don't let the mastectomy comment freak you out Having nice wide margins is definitely very good and from what I have heard and read women tend to do better with wider margins.  Remember some places consider 1mm a sufficient margin(YIKES!!!) but most consider a  2mm margin sufficient.
Posts.Title: How important is your rad. oncologist? LisaF LisaF

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 01:35PM - edited Jan 8, 2009 01:42PM by Liz08 LIsa- I see my rad oncologist regularly for routine follow up and actually call him with any concerns and he always acknowledges my concerns and helps to direct me.   Recently I had a ct-scan for digestive issues which came back normal for digestive issues but the scan showed degenerative changes in my spine and my back has recently been bothering me.  I got nervous with the "degenerative changes" (normally degenerative changes mean arthiritis) and called my rad oncologist who reviewed my actual scan on computer while on the phone with me. He was able to review the ct-scan because I have had all my care done at one facility.  He ordered a bone scan to ease my concerns.  The bone scan being as sensitive as it is, showed one tiny "spot" on my rib but this spot did not show up on the ct-scan. Scans are great but they can also open up a can of worms...in manner of speaking. To rule out anything bad (since the report was very vague) my rad oncologist physically walked (not called) over and followed up with the radiologist who read the bone scan.  Long story short... in the end my rad oncologist had the senior radiologist along with the radiologist(he's new at the hospital) who originally read the scans review my bone scan again along with my rad ongologist and came to the conclusion that this one tiny spot is probably from trauma (I pray that are correct) and am having a repeat bone scan again in March to ease my anxiety. Basically, my rad oncologist is a godsend and he has answered so many questions I needed answers to and I don't know what I would do without him. Good luck in making your decision.
Posts.Title: How important is your rad. oncologist? LisaF LisaF

Posts.Title: Very Angry! LisaG42 BessB

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 06:38PM - edited Mar 5, 2009 07:45AM by Liz08 Karen- I am one of those members who truly believes that with VERY early stage breast cancers (stage 0, stage T1mic, and some Stage T1a), if caught early enough and you are node negative then there's a strong possibility that you can be so called "cured"  after surgery/rads with the addition of a healthy life style even though they no longer use that term "cured" anymore with any type of cancer.   At the age of 38 (mom of 3 young children) I had microinvasive(a focus of less than 1mm of a microinvasion) DCIS that was her2+++ and consulted with over 10 oncologists since I was beside myself after hearing I was her2+++.  They all said that all I needed was radiation after my lumpectomy and told me that if I had only a "few millimeter" invasive component then chemo/Herceptin would have been my treatment without a doubt since being her2+ calls for agressive treatment unlike the standard treatment for those who are her2-. Having a 3 cm tumor is a very large tumor when it comes to breast cancer and being her2+++ makes your tumor VERY agressive.  I recall reading that a her2+ tumor is very seeky and likes to set up shop elsewhere.  Even if you are node negative, cancer cells can enter the blood stream bypassing the nodes.  Usually the larger the tumor the greater the chance especially being her2+++.  You had mentioned that you are going to see a homeopathic doctor, I have several physicians in my family including 2 naturapathic physicians that are trained as homoeopaths, chinese medicine and hold masters in accupuncture and both graduated from Bastyr in Washington. The naturapaths along with my other family members who are regular physicians advised me to seek out several opinions regarding treatment after we learned I was her2+.  And I also see another naturalpath who specializes in women's health and treats alot of breast cancer survivors, after my naturalpath learned I was her2+++ she instructed me to do what my oncologists told me to do for treatment and not to gamble and to come back after I was done with treatment for a treament plan for secondary preventation.  I am speaking to you as a mom speaking to another mom.  You are a very young women with 3 children and I understand that you may not want chemo/Herceptin in your body but don't you want to do everything possible to insure that you will be there for your children?  Natural medidnce has it's place but it doesn't cure cancer. Please visit the her2 website with is an excellent resource for those who are her+, it's www.her2support.org.  Please research your options thoroughly.  Wishing you the very best in your decision making.

Posts.Content: Liz08 wrote: Hi all-  I need your input on costochondritis.  About 4-5 weeks after finishing radiation, I started to experience, pain in the rib area below the breast that was radiated, the pain at times travels  towards my back. I also had pain in the breast, behind the breast and in the chest area etc. This has been going on for over 5 weeks and just started taking Motrin around the clock, was told that's how costochondritis is treated. This does help to take the edge off the pain. The anti-inflamatory (Motrin) is supposed to help bring the inflamation down and help my body to heal. At times I'm short of breath and can't take a deep breath but eventually do catch my breath. I have been examined by a few doctors regarding this and the concensus is costochondritis. They did an oxyen saturation test which came back normal.  Last week my oncologist did a CT scan of my chest just to rule out anything else, thank God everything came back fine. My radiation oncologist also reviewed my ct scan pictures on the computer himself and said that it is a possibility that radiation could have helped to bring this on but that everything on my scan looks great. I do feel better that 2 different doctors (radiologist & radiation oncologist) actually reviewed my ct films. My questions is for those who had costochondritis; what brought it on, how long after radiation did you experience these symptoms, what were your symptoms, how long did they last and how were you treated for it?  Your input would greatly be appreciated.  Thank You. Dx: 1/16/08, Stage T1mic, DCIS, Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2008 01:32PM - edited Dec 12, 2008 01:34PM by Liz08 Jill- when I was 1st diagnosed it seemed like I would have a melt down after 3PM daily. All the sudden I would feel extremely anxious and overwhelmed, I felt like I would enter the twilight zone (I was probably having an anxiety attack). Fortunately this horrible feeling passed after a couple of weeks.  I have 3 young children and I too found myself snapping at them pretty often.  It's normal and you will get passed this point just like the rest of us.  I was prescribed Lorazepam 1mg.  I cut the tablet in 1/2, so I would take .5mg as needed (once a day or sometimes a couple of times during the week).  I would suggest that you take it only when clairly needed since it is habbit forming and only when you don't have to drive.  As far as sleep, I would occasionally take Benadryl (the generic version) and that would help me.  Actually I would rotate the meds sometimes.  Sleep is a very important part of keeping our nervous system healthy. Wishing you the very best, Liz
Posts.Title: anxiety and meds jillisucat jillisucat

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 07:25PM - edited Mar 1, 2010 07:27PM by Liz08 Magentagirl- I am from central CT.  The oncologist I would recommend is Dr. Pat DeFusco from Hartford Hospital, she is very thorough, has an excellent reputation and has a good bed side manner too, she's one of my doctors'.  Another Doctor that has an excellent reputation for breastcancer is Dr. Rabinowe from St. Francis but I heard her bedside manner can be tempermental but she is an excellent oncologist too.    The surgeon's that I would recommend are both from Hartford, Dr. Kristen Zarfos from St. Francis or Dr. Elizabeth Brady from Hartford Hospital.  It's a toss up between the two of them since both are excellent.   As some other members already said, Dr. Orlando Deluca is supposed to be excellent as well. Good luck, Liz

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 06:14PM - edited Jul 17, 2008 07:33PM by Liz08 Faith- you can't assume that you have cancer in your lymph nodes because they're swollen after the biopsy. You did comment that  the nodes have been swollen since the biopsy which may mean that they are reacting to trauma such as the biospy otherwise known as "reactive hyperplasia".  Lymph nodes can swell from a tiny cut or even from shaving under the arm because they are very sensitive and it's their job to fight off infection.   I just found my "post biospy instructions" "no heavy lifting or strenuous exercise for 24 hours, otherwise, you can resume normal activities after this procedure." As far as exercise, verbally I was told it was OK  to exercise (I did running, walking and hand weights) but told  to wait a few days after the biospy.  As Shirlann said may be Beesie can answer some of this better.  I had a hard time with my lumpectomy which I had back in February and am still having alot of pain but everyone is different. Best of luck.

The breast itself, the area behind the breast, and the rib area around the radiated breast hurt so bad that if I laughed, coughed, and forget sneezing  it would bring tears to my eyes.  It did feel muscular at times, especially when I picked up something heavier. I had to stop my brisk walks for a while.  The severe pain lasted for almost 2 months and still hurts somewhat but has much improved and continues to improve.  I was told to take Motrin every 6 hours around the clock for a couple of weeks and my naturalpath also suggesed that I add a supplement called Zyflamed which helped alot.  After having cancer we all like to worry, it's the nature of the beast. Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 03:36PM - edited Jun 17, 2009 08:59PM by Liz08 CherylAnn- your anxiety is understandable.  I too sometimes drive myself crazy seaching the world wide web for answers, especially since I have sooo many lumps in my breasts and it is extremely difficult to keep track of them.  Ignorance is definitely bliss.  I have always been told to look for changes which is very difficult to do with lumpy breasts. What has helped me is to do a BSE around the same day each month and draw a picture of your breast with approx locations of lumps and describe them such a pea sized, grape sized, blueberry sized, penney sized ...soft, hard, movablele etc and compare you monthly diagrams but at times I have labeled a certain lump as a blueberry and now it feels like a large grape (hopefully do to my paranoia) and sometimes I find the opposite but atleast it helps me to see if there are any changes.  Also note any thickening areas, when I was diagnosed with BC, I never had a lump but an area in my outer quadrant that had a thickening and although I have dense breasts the area showed up as mircocalcifications in a digital mammogram.   I have been told that a movable lump is more likely benign then one that doesn't move. If you mammogram and ultra sound come back with nothing, you may want to consider a breast MRI, especially is you have dense breasts to ease your mind. Wishing everything comes back 'BENIGN" .
Posts.Title: mobile lump CherylAnn beacon800

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2008 08:09AM Liz08 wrote: Instead of working I trying to find info on this topic.  Here's some info I found on from : http://www.cancer.org/docroot/CRI/content/CRI_2_4_6x_For_Women_Facing_a_Breast_Biopsy.asp  Does A Biopsy or Surgery Cause Cancer to Spread? In nearly all situations, surgery does not cause cancer to spread. There are some important exceptions, such as tumors in the eyes or testicles. Doctors who are experienced in taking biopsies of cancers and treating them with surgery know how to avoid the danger in these situations. The chances of a needle biopsy causing a cancer to spread are extremely low. In the past, larger needles were used for biopsies, and the chance of spread was higher. One common myth about cancer is that it will spread if it is exposed to air during surgery. Some people may believe this because they often feel worse after the operation than they did before. It is normal to feel this way when you start to recover from any surgery. And sometimes, no one knows that the cancer has spread until it is seen during surgery. Because of this, some people may link surgery with widespread cancer. However, cancer does not spread because it has been exposed to air. If you delay or refuse surgery because of this myth, then you may be harming yourself by passing up effective treatment. But can't find anything on exercise.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2008 07:58AM Liz08 wrote: Faith- you may want to check out pubmed and see if there's any research on this topic.  I remember researching "seeding" of cancer cells during biospy and some studies said it was possible and some studies said it does not happen. It compared needle biopsies to excissional biopsies.  I asked my oncologist this question and she said that we're not sure because of inconclusive studies as the ones I mentioned earlier.  In my opinion I think that seeding is a strong possibility along needle tracks during a biopsy but as far as exercise I just don't think that could spread the cancer.  I think that if the doctors would think you could spread cancer through exercise after a biopsy, then they would say to avoid exercise until you atleast have the results if your biopsy comes back malignant or benign.    You may also want to post this question on John Hopkins ask an expert forum which is open to questions on many weekends.  Let us know what your doctors tell you, I'm curious as to their answer.
